snippet: In the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy, businesses have gone into overdrive on “cause marketing,” tapping charitable impulses while advancing their own interests, occasionally to unseemly effect.
abstract: Ginia Bellafante Big City column contends that 'cause marketing,' practice in which companies promise to donate percentage of proceeds to charitable cause, like Hurricane Sand relief, is problematic because of subjectivity of word 'proceeds'; says it is often more effective to make straight donations, noting that while charitable events surrounding Hurricane Sandy are abundant, they have raised relatively little money.
lead_paragraph: In the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy, businesses have gone into overdrive on “cause marketing,” tapping charitable impulses while advancing their own interests, occasionally to unseemly effect.

headline.seo: Hurricane Sandy Donations — 15 Percent of What?
